Burney Forest Power   5 Year RMP Update

Executive Summary Text File

This document represents the updated and revised Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the
cogeneration facility operated by North American Energy Services (NAES), under the name of
Burney Forest Power (BFP) located in Burney, California. The facility is an existing operating
source. This document has been prepared in order to address the following issues:

     Acknowledge the operation of an existing source with processes subject to the RMP
regulations and requirements.
     Incorporate revisions to the RMP pursuant to the requirements of the CalARP and 40
CFR 68 regulations.

The RMP addresses the requirements of the California Accidental Release Program (CalARP) as
adopted by the State of California as outlined in California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19.
These federal and state requirements build upon the provisions of the "general duty clause" of the
Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, and the federal RMP program requirements in 40 Code of
Federal Regulations (CFR) 68, which require the following activities of all facilities which
produce, process, store, or handle listed substances:

     identify hazards
     design and maintain a safe facility
     prevent releases
     minimize the consequences of releases.

The required approach to accomplishing the above, pursuant to the CalARP and Federal RMP
regulations, is to have a documented risk management plan, which outlines the steps and
procedures a facility must take to prevent and mitigate accidental releases. BFP has chosen to
prepare and implement its RMP for the anhydrous ammonia system in order to fulfill its
obligations with respect to the RMP regulations and the General Duty clause and to protect its
employees and the surrounding community from the effects of accidental releases.

Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.155 and CCR Title 19, Section 2745.3, the following summary is given:

This updated/revised RMP applies to the BFP facility located at:

35586-C Highway 299E
Burney, CA. 96013

Facility Description and Regulated Substances

The BFP facility consists of two biomass-fired (wood) boilers, which produce a gross electric
power output of 28.4 MW. Principal process equipment includes the boilers, steam turbine, air
pollution control systems, fuel handling systems, ammonia storage and delivery system, and
cooling tower. The site elevation is approximately 3250 ft. above mean sea level. The exhaust
stack heights are approximately 125 ft. above grade.
 
Emission controls incorporate Best Available Control Technology (BACT). Each boiler is
equipped with electrostatic precipitators for control of particulate matter, and ammonia injection
(Thermal DeNOx) for the control of NOx emissions. Anhydrous ammonia is used as the NOx
reduction reagent. A 12,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia storage tank is currently used at the site.
Additional project components include a power distribution center, continuous emission
monitoring system, fuel handling and ash processing systems.

Substance Used/Stored: Anhydrous Ammonia  (CAS# 1336-21-6)
Facility SIC: 4911  NAICS Code: 221112

The accidental release prevention and emergency action policies at the facility are delineated in
Sections 4.0 and 14.0 respectively. A brief description of the prevention and emergency response
policies is as follows.

Accident Prevention Program Policies and Elements

The accident prevention program is implemented through an established set of policies and
programs including, but not limited to, the following:

     Inspection and maintenance program for all system equipment.
     Monitoring of employee and contractor use of the systems.
     Contractor Safety Program
     Emergency Response Plan
     Lockout/Tagout Procedures and Program
     Hot Work Permit Program
     Confined Space Entry Program
     Employee Safety Training Program
     Compil

ation of substance information (MSDS)
     Incident investigation procedures
     Periodic compliance audits.
     Compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations.

Integral parts of the prevention program are the following plans:

Hazardous Materials Business Plan   Injury and Illness Prevention Plan   Spill Containment
Control and Countermeasure Plan   Hazardous Waste Storage and Handling Procedures  
Hazard Communication Program   Fire Protection and Prevention Procedures   Hearing
Conservation Program   Respiratory Conservation Program   Electrical Safety Program  
Proposition 65 Compliance Program   Forklift and Industrial Truck Program   Welding, Cutting,
and Brazing Safety Program.

These plans are kept on site for inspection during normal business hours.
Emergency Action Policies and Elements

The emergency response program is implemented through an established set of policies and
programs including, but not limited to, the following:

     Establishment of criteria defining an emergency
     Staff training and responsibility assignments
     Emergency notification procedures (on and off-site)
     Evacuation procedures
     Written emergency response procedures
     Coordination of emergency response with local authorities
     Incident investigation and follow-up procedures

Release Scenario Data

The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the anhydrous ammonia storage tank with full
containment. This scenario results in the release of approximately 51,000 pounds of ammonia.
The distance to the toxic endpoint is approximately 700 meters and may affect approximately 8
individuals within census tract 127.01, i.e., the zone of impact.
The alternate release scenario is the failure of the system transfer piping with the spill contents
being discharged to existing ground surfaces. This scenario results in the release of
approximately 100 pounds of ammonia. The distance to the toxic endpoint is within th

e plant
fence-line boundary and may affect approximately 0 individuals within census tract 127.01, i.e.,
the zone of impact.

The piping and distribution network is equipped with a number of manual and automatic valves,
which effectively limit the amount and duration of any accidental release. System pressures and
flow rates are monitored at the main plant control room console. In addition, the tank and
secondary containment area is equipped with a water deluge system and ammonia sensors.

The general accidental release prevention program is comprised of the following elements:

     Proper maintenance of all system equipment.
     Proper operation of all system equipment.
     Internal operating policies with respect to ammonia tank capacity.
     Comprehensive personnel training.
     A written emergency response plan.
     A written hazardous materials management plan.
     Documented safety procedures for employees and contractors.
     Inclusion of ammonia specific health, safety, and response data in the RMP.

The facility is an existing source and has never experienced an accidental release of ammonia or
any other hazardous substance in the last 5 years.

The current emergency response plan and procedures for BFP are discussed in detail in Section
14.0 and Appendix H. The Burney Fire Department (BFD) will be the first responder in an
ammonia emergency. BFP personnel will perform "awareness" duties only, which simply means
that once the ammonia spill or release is discovered, BFP personnel will make the proper
notifications and set the emergency procedures in motion. BFD will handle spill/release response
and mitigation. In the event of a major release, BFP may join forces with BFD and State/County
OES personnel in a "unified command effort" until the emergency has been mitigated.

Chemical Specific Prevention Elements

Chemical specific prevention measures are summarized as follows:

     Periodic inspection of ammonia tank,

containment area, pumps, piping network, flow
controllers, and injection grid.
     Monitoring of tank and system pressures and temperatures.
     Monitoring of unloading/delivery procedures.
     Installation and use of ammonia detector(s) in the main tank area.
     Provide all required safety and response equipment.
     Provide a chemical specific training program.
     Access to the BFP facility site is controlled, and the facility is fenced.

Review of the P&IDs (Appendix C) indicates that there are numerous pressure, temperature, and
level indicator sensors, which will be reported directly to the distributed control system (DCS)
for operator confirmation and action.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

     Presently, NAES is operating a number of similar power plant facilities across the nation.
Data developed from the operational experience at these facilities will be directly applied to the
operation and safety aspects of the BFP facility, and vice versa. Operational and safety issues
identified at any NAES facility are immediately analyzed for applicability to other operational
sites. Additionally, the following will be used to identify and track safety improvements at BFP.

     Completion of the revised HazOp for the BFP facility (February 25, 2004)
     Required periodic updating of the HazOp per the CalARP regulations
     Implementation and revision to safety and training procedures
     Completion of the required RMP audits, updates, and certifications
     Continuation of inspections by the Administering Agency (County Environmental Health
Dept.)
     Use of the pre-startup review procedures

The facility will constantly strive for improved performance and reliability from all its processes.
As specific process and safety improvements are identified they will be evaluated by staff for
application and implementation.


Training

The facility staff, as well as NAES corporate staff, understands that incidents involv

ing the
accidental release of listed substances can be reduced and/or eliminated by having trained
operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating
procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program.

The current training program is comprised of the following:

     Initial employee training
     Periodic re-training and certification
     Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification per the MoC
     Refresher training
     Training records for each employee


Mechanical Integrity

The mechanical integrity element of the plant operations procedures ensures that new and
modified equipment or processes are manufactured to meet process requirements, that they are
installed correctly, and subsequently maintained in safe operating condition. 

The facility's mechanical integrity system is contained within the plant operation and
maintenance manuals. The system manuals delineate such practices as:

     Equipment or process inspection techniques and frequency
     Preventative maintenance schedules
     Maintenance requirements and procedures
     History of maintenance
     Process identification, model numbers, and serial numbers
     Maintenance logs (who performed the maintenance, and information on the maintenance
activity, etc.)

In addition, the program contains the following elements:

     Written maintenance, testing, and inspection procedures and schedules.
     Maintenance training.
     Maintenance documentation.
     Deficiency correction procedures and documentation.
     New equipment quality assurance procedures.

Pre-Startup Review

The pre-startup review applies to additions or modifications, which require the process safety
information to be updated. The facility pre-startup safety review procedure is contained within
the plant operations manuals. The review generally addresses the following issu

es:

     Equipment designed and installed according to prevailing industry standards and
specifications.
     Construction per existing building codes and standards.
     Adequate safety and emergency procedures are developed and implemented.
     Process Hazards Analysis (PHA, Hazop) performed prior to startup.
     Management of Change (MoC) procedures initiated and completed.
     Training of affected employees initiated and completed.

Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to
the need for a pre-startup safety review. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the
MoC review. Additionally, a pre-startup safety review will be performed in conjunction with the
MoC review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety procedures. 

A pre-startup checklist has been developed to document the pre-startup safety review and to
ensure that all of the requirements were addressed prior to the delivery and/or use of any
regulated substances. The checklist ensures that the following steps are taken prior to startup:

     Design specification review is conducted for the new or modified equipment and
construction. Design and equipment specifications are verified and the design codes and
standards adhere to generally accepted good engineering practices.
     Operating, maintenance, safety, and emergency procedures are revised or developed as
necessary. 
     For proposed new processes, P&IDs are reviewed and confirmed complete, and a PHA is
performed. 
     For modified processes, the P&IDs are updated and the PHA is revised as necessary.
     If employee job classifications or job tasks will be affected, training is completed in
accordance with all required standards.

Incident Investigations

Thorough investigation of "incidents" (any occurrence that results in or could result in
catastrophic releases of anhydrous ammonia) or "near misses" (any situation where conditi

ons
existed under which an incident could have occurred, but did not) is another essential element of
the RMP program. Incident investigations typically yield perspectives on equipment or process
safety that are not normally apparent to plant operations and maintenance staff, such as:

     Incident "causes" outside of the PHA scope.
     Was the facility response appropriate?
     Did the Emergency Response Plan (ERP) function as designed?
     Did the ERP and RMP provide the necessary level of protection with respect to the offsite
impacts?
     What changes need to be made to the RMP and ERP to ensure an appropriate response in
the future?
Incident investigations pursuant to this RMP will be specific to the anhydrous ammonia process
system. The following data is typically gathered by the incident investigation team subsequent to
the incident:

     Date and time of the "incident" or "near miss"
     Timeliness of incident report to the responding agency
     Timeliness of public awareness and/or evacuation measures
     Description of the incident or "near miss"
     An evaluation of the events that resulted in the incident or "near miss"
     Recommendations to prevent future occurrences of the incident

The incident investigation policy is delineated in the safety procedures. The investigation results,
including the implementation of all recommendations, are reviewed with facility staff whose job
responsibilities are relevant to the findings. Copies of the investigation reports are maintained on
site for a minimum of five years, and are used during the periodic PHA re-evaluations.

Employee Participation

The facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees (including
contractors) at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. Operational safety is achieved
by a constant exchange of information with employees to ensure consideration of their
knowledge and experience in all applicable area

s of the prevention program. The facility has
implemented procedures regarding employee participation in the prevention program elements,
the hazard assessment, and emergency action program. The written employee participation plan
and facility policies ensures that:

     Employees at all staff levels are participants in the development and implementation of
PHAs. 
     Employees at all staff levels are participants in the development of the prevention
program elements, the hazard assessment, and the emergency action program.
     Employees at all staff levels are given access to PHA data, ERP data, offsite consequence
data, plan implementation data, etc.

Management of Change

Operational, safety, and environmental issues must be addressed whenever a change occurs at a
facility, which involves an affected process or substance. Quite often a change made in one
aspect of the process may affect other parts of the process due to facility system integration. Such
changes must be reviewed prior to initiation, to ensure that they do not compromise the
operational safety and integrity of the process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety
and public health. The facility MoC procedures are used to evaluate all changes to the following
types of systems:

     Process chemicals (delivery, storage, handling)
     Control technology systems (operation rates, chemicals used, by-products or wastes
produced)
     Equipment design and construction
     Operations and maintenance procedures
     Other changes to facility equipment or processes

The current MoC procedures, developed by NAES and plant staff, are used for the BFP facility to
track changes in equipment or processes as identified or planned by facility personnel. Plant staff
evaluate the potential impact(s) of the change on operational safety and worker health via a
checklist for minor changes or a design review for major changes. The following steps are taken
to ensure the safe

implementation of the change.

     Prior to startup, process safety information is updated as required. Revised process safety
information is placed in the operations, safety, and maintenance manuals.
     Operating procedures are revised in accordance with the new or modified equipment or
process design and operations specifications. Updated procedures are placed in the appropriate
operations, safety, and maintenance manuals.
     Employees affected by the change (job classification basis) receive training in accordance
with the specific training program prior to startup of the process. The employees training records
are updated.

The operations staff, in conjunction with the RMP team, is responsible for evaluating a process
or procedural change to ensure compliance with the RMP regulations and MoC program
requirements.
